content:
just to be clear.

Incoming mail comes through one of two protocols. POP or IMAP. Outgoing mail goes using SMTP regardless of the incoming protocol used.

So in essence each email account is two accounts, one incoming and one outgoing. That server name looks suspiciously like that used by a hosting company. Are your email accounts on a hosted site?

I looked at digital pacific and they have these settings on their site for email https://support.digitalpacific.com.au/en/knowledgebase/article/general-email-settings

Those server names and the ones in your error do not look like they will ever matchup. So what exactly is in outgoing server (SMTP) for your accounts that are not working? There needs to be an entry in there for all three email addresses used with the correct username and password for the email address.
creator: MattAuSupport

When I started Thunderbird just now, it sent an email from the unsent messages that had been there for a couple of days. Other test emails from the two accounts that haven't been working also went without a problem! So at the moment they're working again.

The speed of the internet here is not great. Would that make any difference? That's the only other thing I can think of. Why would it work one day and not the next? Frustrating.

content:
Hi Greg,

Some things to try :

The SMTP server in the error is listed as vmpc65.digitalpacific.com.au Is this just a description ? Even so maybe try changing it to the format specified in the info for your provider.

I would expect this should be mail.digitalpacific.net.au The name of the server should be here which is not specific to your email address

The company list their settings as : Outgoing Server: mail.yourdomain.net.au Encryption method: SSL SMTP Port: 465

Where your domain is I am assuming digitalpacific

If you are using the SSL encryption settings, have you tried enabling DNS over HTTPS in thunderbird ? and see if that helps ?

Hope this helps, some.
creator: jennydeione

content:
greg152 said
The speed of the internet here is not great. Would that make any difference? That's the only other thing I can think of. Why would it work one day and not the next? Frustrating.

Internet speed only becomes an issue when the message size is large and you have outgoing email scanning enabled (it significantly delays sending usually). With both those things you can experience timeouts on the connection, but those usually generate an error message as the timeout aborts the transfer that has commenced.

However sometimes outgoing scanning messes up the connection and a newer version "just gets installed" and the problem goes away. (Think Crowdstrike, they released a very good example of a poor update, but these software updates that you are not even notified of are occurring sometimes daily with security software that is deeply embedded in your system.)

What is far more common is sending or receiving or both are blocked by antivirus products because the version of Thunderbird is new and their rather dodgy software firewalls have not received a note from home that Thunderbird has a new version, but I really do not think that was your issue as the server was contacted and refusing connection. This sometime is the result of too many incorrect password attempts say, which results in a timed lockout for a day or until someone at the provider lifts it.

But if it is working, lets just leave well enough alone.

content:
It sounds like Thunderbird is encountering a security warning related to accessing your Gmail account via OAuth2. Here's a step-by-step approach to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:

1. Clear Thunderbird Cache: 

  Sometimes, cached data can cause issues. Try clearing Thunderbird's cache:   - Open Thunderbird.   - Go to Help > Troubleshooting Information.   - Click on Open Folder next to Application Basics.   - Close Thunderbird completely.   - In the folder that opens, locate and delete the `cache2` folder.

2. Check Date and Time Settings: 

  Ensure your computer's date, time, and timezone settings are correct. Incorrect settings can sometimes trigger security warnings.

3. Verify Google Security Settings: 

  Double-check the security settings in your Google account:   - Go to your Google account settings (https://myaccount.google.com/security).   - Look under Third-party apps with account access and ensure Thunderbird is listed and allowed.   - If Thunderbird is listed, try removing it from the list and re-adding it after attempting to set it up again in Thunderbird.

4. Try a Different Browser: 

  When you click on "Allow" in Thunderbird to authorize access to your Google account, it opens a browser window. Try using a different browser to see if the issue persists.

5. Check Thunderbird Updates: 

  Ensure Thunderbird is up to date. Sometimes, updates include fixes for OAuth2 authentication issues.

6. Firewall and Security Software: 

  Temporarily disable any third-party firewall or security software that might be blocking Thunderbird's connection to Google servers. Ensure Windows Defender or any other antivirus software is not interfering.

7. Re-add Gmail Account in Thunderbird: 

  After performing the above steps, attempt to re-add your Gmail account in Thunderbird:   - Go to Tools > Account Settings   - Click on Account Actions > Add Mail Account.   - Follow the prompts, including OAuth2 authentication steps.

8. Contact Thunderbird Support: 

  If the issue persists after trying these steps, consider reaching out to Thunderbird support or checking their community forums for additional assistance specific to Thunderbird's OAuth2 issues.

By systematically checking these steps, you should be able to trace out and resolve the problem preventing you from re-installing your Gmail account on Thunderbird.

content: Yes, attempting to upload 20g is a huge problem, as IMAP was never designed for that. Getting your messages from a POP account to an IMAP account requires careful uploading, preferably in small chunks. Creating a manual filter to copy from local folders to the IMAP account is a technique with a history of success, but I encourage spot checking messages after the upload to ensure messages are complete. I have no idea on why you cannot delete the POP account, but others here may have suggestions.

content:
Microsoft logo

Le 16 septembre 2024, les applications qui utilisent une technologie de connexion moins sécurisée ne pourront plus accéder à votre courrier.

La sécurité de vos informations est la priorité absolue de Microsoft Corporation. Pour préserver la sécurité de votre compte, Microsoft Corporation ne prendra plus en charge l’utilisation d’applications de Courrier et calendrier Outlook tierces qui vous demandent de vous connecter avec uniquement les nom d’utilisateur et mot de passe de votre compte Microsoft. Pour accroître votre sécurité, vous devrez utiliser une application de Courrier ou de calendrier Outlook qui prend en charge les méthodes d’authentification moderne de Microsoft Corporation. Si vous n’agissez pas, vos applications de Courrier Outlook tierces ne seront plus en mesure d’accéder à votre adresse de courriel Outlook.com, Hotmail ou Live.com le 16 septembre 2024.

Que devez-vous faire?

Si vous recevez ce courriel, vous utilisez actuellement une application de Courrier ou de calendrier Outlook qui se sert d’une méthode d’authentification moins sécurisée pour la connexion à votre compte de courrier Outlook.com. Vous devrez mettre à niveau vos applications de Courrier et de calendrier Outlook tierces vers une version qui prend en charge les méthodes d’authentification modernes.

Microsoft Corporation propose des versions gratuites d’Outlook pour vos ordinateurs personnels et appareils Mac, iOS et Android qui peuvent être facilement téléchargées et connectées à votre compte de courrier. L’utilisation d’une version mise à jour d’une application Outlook garantit que vous vous connectez de la façon la plus sécurisée.

Comment pouvez-vous configurer votre application de Courrier Gmail, Apple Mail ou tierce?

Différentes applications non-Microsoft Corporation comporteront leur propre procédure de connexion à votre compte de courrier Outlook.com avec des méthodes d’authentification modernes. Consultez notre article d’aide – Méthodes d’authentification moderne à présent nécessaires pour poursuivre la synchronisation du courrier Outlook dans les applications de courrier non-Microsoft Corporation. Toutefois, vous devrez peut-être contacter les créateurs de ces applications pour obtenir des instructions. Dans bien des cas, il suffira de supprimer et de rajouter votre compte avec la dernière version de cette application afin qu’il soit configuré pour utiliser les méthodes d’authentification modernes.

Déclaration de confidentialité

Microsoft Corporation, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052 USA

content: The correct settings are: incoming IMAP outlook.office365.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address; outgoing smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2, email address. A single oauth:// token will be added to Saved Passwords that applies to both incoming and outgoing.

content: The outgoing server will apply the same oauth:// token in Saved Passwords for the incoming server, as long as you have the account sending on the correct server. Select the account in the left pane of Account Settings, then in the right pane, Outgoing Server (SMTP), make sure the smtp has the correct settings and the same User Name as the selected account (click Edit SMTP server to view the settings).

content: If Thunderbird is prompting you to change your Hotmail password and won't log in, it may be due to OAuth authentication issues or other security measures implemented by Microsoft. First, log in to your Hotmail account through a web browser to check for any security alerts or unusual activity that might require a password change. Ensure that your Thunderbird is updated to the latest version, as updates often include fixes for authentication issues. You may need to re-authenticate by removing and re-adding your Hotmail account in Thunderbird, which will prompt a new OAuth authorization. Verify your server settings in Thunderbird to match Microsoft's current recommendations, particularly the authentication method (usually OAuth2 for IMAP). Additionally, if you have two-step verification enabled, consider using an app password. If these steps do not resolve the issue, you may need to change your password as a last resort to comply with any new security protocols Microsoft has introduced.

Immediately on starting I was warned again about cookie settings so I allowed these, checked all the settings again, and attempted to send an email. A MS pop-up requested my PW, so I input it, and at last all seems to work! F.i. I had to remove and re-add the Hotmail account in my Android phone, changing the settings as necessary. This did not succeed until after a total shutdown and re-start of the phone. During the settings changes I could not find any reference to OAuth, but all seems to be in good working order. So success, after a struggle that I think was largely due to my inadequacy. I am very grateful to NoahSumo. sfhowes, and Mywebsite for your knowledgeable and generous help. Tom. (P.S. content:
Thanks for the two replies so far. Regrettably they do not address the primary problem: How do I retrieve the roughly 40,000 messages from 2008 to 2022?

I understand the problem of bandwidth, but two days later, I still cannot retrieve the older messages and I cannot figure out why Thunderbird, apparently at random, started retrieving the messages beginning in December 2022 rather than in 2008.

content:
ok so I finally managed ... I had to login to the OWA ... go to settings>calendar (https://outlook.office.com/calendar/options/calendar/view) select "Shared calendars" and publish your calendar (all events) .. this will generate two links HTML + ICS ..

copy the ICS link .. go to TB > CAlendar > New Calendar > Network ... add your username and paste the link as location ... and there you go :)

There is only once catch for now.. it's one way sync .. so I cannot create events from TB but at least I am one step closer (and have all calendars in one place) ..
creator: fkoudelka666

content:
more than 10 years ago I wrote this blog post. https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2011/11/thunderbird-and-exchange-owa.html

Both the davmail project and the exquilla addon are both still around, although the exquilla addon is now maintained by the same folk that do OWL. So you have choices. I used DavMail on my own exchange server back at the time. But have avoided anything exchange for more than a decade so I have no current knowledge.

Essentially this issue Is an extension of the process you had to go through to have Thunderbird as a permitted application to connect. The addon is as far as Microsoft is concerned another application. So it needs the administrator of the exchange tenant to allow it access, just as Thunderbird needed to b3e allowed access. The page you have will pass a request to the designated authority for that tenant.

publish your calendar (all events) .. this will generate two links HTML + ICS ..

Generally speaking any ICS file linked to on a URL will be loaded read only. There are exceptions but they are few and far between and do not include Microsoft anything as far as I am aware. They all require authentication.

Your support for the TBsync addon and it's addition the EAS addon is actually provided by the addon author and he provides an email address on the downloads page to contact and ask specific questions. Have you approached him about your issues with the addon?
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I tried, but the exquilla needs an admin's approval too :(

content: anyway.. I managed with OWL for Exchange.... tho, it costs 10eur / year .. but I will probably do that

content:
These instruction work well: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

and here is the shorthand version of that: Here is how i do it: - exit thunderbird on old PC - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media (this assumes you use default installation) - on new PC, install thunderbird and exit - copy the backed-up thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird folder - start thunderbird

content: Top left blue button '+New Message' click on it, new window opens In new window top right 'Attach' Button next to a paper clip, click on the button opens a new window for you to browser to your file to attach. Click Open once file selected, window closes and your file to attach is listed at the bottom of the compose window. Once email written, click send button (top left) on the compose window email sent and copied to sent folder.
creator: jennydeione

content:
Como he respondido en otro mensaje más abajo, Microsoft ha decidido que a partir de ahora las cuentas de Outlook, Hotmail y Live ya no puedan utilizarse bajo el protocolo POP y los métodos de autenticación utilizados con el mismo, y ahora exige protocolo IMAP y método de autentificación OAuth2.

Desde la opción de Thunderbird "Herramientas -> Configuración de cuenta" no lo vas a poder cambiar. Así que te toca eliminar las cuentas de correo de Outlook (u otras de Microsoft) y volverlas a crear de forma automática para que se creen ellas mismas directamente con el protocolo IMAP y método de autenticación OAuth2 exigidos por Microsoft.

Antes de esto, si tiene correos de dichas cuentas en Bandeja de Entrada que quieras conservar, guárdalos en otra carpeta porque lo más probable es que desaparezcan de ahí al eliminarlas.
creator: imnovix

content: Hola Imnovix. Muchas gracias por tu respuesta. La apliqué en 2 cuentas de Hotmail (las mas "livianas") y anduvo todo bien. Los mensajes en Bandeja de Entrada no se perdieron, de modo que no tuve que recurrir a la copia de respaldo que había hecho. Ahora me toca hacerlo con una cuenta de Outlook que es muy grande, con un centenar de subcarpetas. ¿Es recomendable guardar también la carpeta Enviados, o con ella no hay riesgos de perder los mensajes? Nuevamente gracias y cordial saludo.
creator: degiorgi

content:
degiorgi dijo
Hola Imnovix. Muchas gracias por tu respuesta. La apliqué en 2 cuentas de Hotmail (las mas "livianas") y anduvo todo bien. Los mensajes en Bandeja de Entrada no se perdieron, de modo que no tuve que recurrir a la copia de respaldo que había hecho. Ahora me toca hacerlo con una cuenta de Outlook que es muy grande, con un centenar de subcarpetas. ¿Es recomendable guardar también la carpeta Enviados, o con ella no hay riesgos de perder los mensajes? Aparentemente sigo teniendo todos los mensajes enviados de las cuentas de Outlook que eliminé y volví a crear de forma automática. Pero si son muy importantes los tuyos, igual no estaría mal hacer una copia, por si acaso.

A mí lo que sí me ocurrió fue lo de que desaparecieron de la Bandeja de Entrada, desapareciendo también de sus propias carpetas individuales. Afortunadamente no eran importantes.

Ah, una cosa que se me olvidó mencionar, es que puede que Microsoft insista en pedirte las contraseñas de cada una de las cuentas recién creadas. Pero al cabo de unos días por fin "se cansa" y le basta con que se las proporcione Thunderbird sin tu intervención.
creator: imnovix

content: First, I do not have the expertise to project why your version was skipped, as there were more releases of ver 91, as shown in this URL: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/ Generally, however, that message appears when you are on the final version of a release. To upgrade, my suggesion is this: - do a full backup of the profile just for safety (I always do this prior to an upgrade) . If on windows, the simple way is to exit thunderbird and copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to anywhere else. - then download 102.0.1 so you benefit from any upgrade fixes. - then repeat for 115.0.1 for further updates - then update to 115.13 - and then repeat the backup process explained above. At this point, you are positioned for the autorelease of 128.
creator: davidsk

content: That message you are showing in the image is from your antivirus. It is also probably the reason you are not getting mail. Try disabling it's email scanning features. They have a long history of dropping the ball when they encounter a malformed email (which is usually but not always spam) and everything just stops. Remove the scanner and everything just works again.
creator: MattAuSupport

Repair folder deleted nothing. It does however occasionally show up emails that were already missing as it rebuilds the index into the file the messages are stored in.

Right click the folder and select properties and then look at the size on disk of the content of the folder. is it almost nothing? or might another repair fix the index that an antivirus program may have prevented being correctly written.
